API¶

color.py¶

Functions for working with colors.

class algoraphics.color.Color(hsl=None, hue=None, sat=None, li=None, rgb=None, RGB=None)¶

Object to represent a color or distribution of colors.

Define using any of an hsl tuple, separate hue/saturation/lightness arguments, an rgb tuple (0 to 1), or an RGB tuple (integers 0 to 255). Any component can be a Param object.

Parameters:
  • hsl (Optional[Tuple[float, float, float]]) – The hsl specification, where each component is between 0 and 1.
  • hue (Optional[float]) – The hue specification from 0 to 1. sat and li must also be provided.
  • sat (Optional[float]) – The saturation specification from 0 to 1.
  • li (Optional[float]) – The lightness specification from 0 to 1.
  • rgb (Optional[Tuple[float, float, float]]) – The red/green/blue components, each ranging from 0 to 1.
  • RGB (Optional[Tuple[int, int, int]]) – The red/green/blue components, each ranging from 0 to 255.
RGB()¶

Get the color’s RGB specification.

Returns one fixed specification if the color is parameterized.

Return type:Tuple[int, int, int]
hex()¶

Get the color’s hsl specification.

Returns one fixed specification if the color is parameterized.

Return type:str
rgb()¶

Get the color’s rgb specification.

Returns one fixed specification if the color is parameterized.

Return type:Tuple[float, float, float]
value()¶

Get the color’s hsl specification.

Returns one fixed specification if the color is parameterized.

Return type:Tuple[float, float, float]
algoraphics.color.average_color(colors)¶

Find average of list of colors.

Currently, this finds the arithmetic mean in RGB color space.

Parameters:colors (Sequence[Color]) – A list of Color objects.
Return type:Color
Returns:The average color.
algoraphics.color.contrasting_lightness(color, light_diff)¶

Get color with contrasting lightness to reference color.

Color is lighter if original lightness is < 0.5 and darker otherwise. Used to create color pairs for a mixture of light and dark colors.

Parameters:
  • color (Color) – A color.
  • light_diff (float) – Magnitude of difference in lightness, between 0 and 1.
Return type:

Color
Returns:

The contrasting color.
algoraphics.color.hsv_array_to_rgb(hsv)¶

Convert matrix of HSV values to rgb.

Parameters:hsv (ndarray) – An array of HSV colors.
Return type:ndarray
Returns:An array of rgb colors.
algoraphics.color.make_color(x)¶

Convert to a color object if a tuple is provided.

Return type:Color
algoraphics.color.map_colors_to_array(values, colors, gradient_mode='rgb')¶

Map 2D array of values to a cyclical color gradient.

If values vary continuously in space, this produces a cyclical color gradient.

Parameters:
  • values (ndarray) – A 2D array of floats. Values should range from 0, inclusive, to len(colors) + 1, exclusive. Each value corresponds to a proportional mixture of the colors at the two indices it is between (with values higher than the last index cycling back to the first color).
  • colors (Sequence[Color]) – A list of Color objects.
  • gradient_mode (str) – Either ‘rgb’ or ‘hsv’ to indicate how the colors are interpolated.
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

A 3D array of RGB values (RGB mode because this is used for PIL images).
algoraphics.color.rgb_array_to_hsv(rgb)¶

Convert matrix of rgb values to HSV.

Parameters:rgb (ndarray) – An array of rgb colors.
Return type:ndarray
Returns:An array of HSV colors.

fill.py¶

Fill regions with objects in various ways.

class algoraphics.fill.Doodle(function, footprint)¶

A Doodle object is a generator of doodles.

Parameters:
  • function (Callable[[], Union[dict, list]]) – A function that takes no arguments and returns a shape or collection.
  • footprint (ndarray) – A boolean 2D array whose cells indicate the shape (within a grid) occupied by the generated doodles (before being oriented). Row 0 should correspond to the top row of the doodle’s footprint.
footprint(orientation=0)¶

Get the doodle’s footprint in a given orientation.

Parameters:orientation (int) – 0 to 7.
Return type:ndarray
Returns:The oriented footprint.
oriented(orientation=0)¶

Draw the doodle in a given orientation.

Parameters:orientation (int) – 0 to 7.
Return type:Union[dict, list]
Returns:The oriented doodle.
algoraphics.fill.filament_fill(direction_delta, width, seg_length, color)¶

Generate filament fill function.

Parameters:
  • direction_delta (Param) – Parameter that will become the delta for the filament direction.
  • width (Union[int, float]) – Width of the filament.
  • seg_length (Union[int, float]) – Average side length of each segment.
  • color (Color) – Color specification for filament segments. A separate copy is used for each filament in case it involves deltas/ratios.
Return type:

Callable[[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]], List[dict]]
Returns:

A function used by fill_region().
algoraphics.fill.fill_region(outline, object_fun, max_tries=None)¶

Fill a region by iteratively placing randomly generated objects.

Parameters:
  • outline (Union[dict, list]) – A shape or (nested) list of shapes that will become clip.
  • object_fun (Callable[[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]], Union[dict, list]]) – A function that takes bounds as input and returns one randomly generated object. Usually this is a lambda function that calls another function using arguments passed to the function that produced the lambda function. i.e., def caller_fun(args…): return lambda bounds: helper_fun(bounds, args…)
  • max_tries (Optional[int]) – If not None, the number of objects to generate (including those discarded for not filling space) before giving up and returning the region as is.
Return type:

dict
Returns:

A group with clip.
algoraphics.fill.fill_spots(outline, spacing=10, radius=None)¶

Fill a region with randomly sized spots.

The spots are reminiscent of Ishihara color blindness tests. The spots are not completely non-overlapping, but overlaps are somewhat avoided by spacing out their centers.

Parameters:
  • outline (Union[dict, list]) – A region outline shape.
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – The approximate distance between the centers of neighboring spots.
  • radius (Optional[Param]) – The spot radius. By default the radii range from spacing to spacing / 5 in a geometric sequence. If provided, it is recommended to supply a parameter with ratio < 1 so that spaced-out larger points are plotted first, with progressively smaller points inserted between existing ones.
Return type:

List[dict]
Returns:

A list of circle shapes.
algoraphics.fill.fill_wrapping_paper(outline, spacing, doodles, rotate=True)¶

Fill a region with a tiling of non-overlapping doodles.

Parameters:
  • outline (Union[dict, list]) – A shape or (nested) list of shapes that will become the clip.
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – Height/width of each grid cell.
  • doodles (Sequence[Doodle]) – A list of Doodle objects.
  • rotate (bool) – Whether to place the grid in a random rotated orientation.
Return type:

dict
Returns:

A clipped group.
algoraphics.fill.grid_wrapping_paper(rows, cols, spacing, start, doodles)¶

Create a tiling of non-overlapping doodles.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows to include.
  • cols (int) – Number of columns to include.
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – Height/width of each grid cell.
  • start (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – Bottom left point of the grid.
  • doodles (Sequence[Doodle]) – A list of Doodle objects.
Return type:

List[Union[dict, list]]
Returns:

A list of placed doodle collections.

geom.py¶

General functions involving points in 2D space.

class algoraphics.geom.Rtree(points=None)¶

An object to efficiently query a field of points.

Parameters:points (Optional[Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]]) – Starting points.
add_point(point)¶

Add a point to the collection.

Parameters:point (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The new point.
add_points(points)¶

Add points to the collection.

Parameters:points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – The new points.
nearest(point, n=1, index=False)¶

Get the nearest point or points to a query point.

Parameters:
  • point (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – A query point.
  • n (int) – Number of nearest points to return.
  • index (bool) – Whether to return the nearets points’ indices instead of the points themselves.
Return type:

Union[Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]], Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]
Returns:

If n is 1, the nearest point, otherwise a list of nearest points.
algoraphics.geom.angle_between(p1, p2, p3)¶

Get the angle (in radians) between segment p2->p1 and p2->p3.

The angle can be negative.

Parameters:
  • p1 (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The first endpoint.
  • p2 (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The point where the angle is calculated.
  • p3 (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The other endpoint.
Return type:

float
algoraphics.geom.deg(rad)¶

Convert radians to degrees.

Return type:float
algoraphics.geom.direction_to(p1, p2)¶

Get the direction of p2 from p1 in degrees.

Return type:float
algoraphics.geom.distance(p1, p2)¶

Get the distance between two points.

Return type:float
algoraphics.geom.endpoint(start, angle, distance)¶
Parameters:
  • start (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – Starting point.
  • angle (Union[int, float]) – Direction from starting point in radians.
  • distance (Union[int, float]) – Distance from starting point.
Return type:

Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]
Returns:

A point distance from start in the direction angle.
algoraphics.geom.get_nearest(points, point, index=False)¶

Find the nearest point in a list to a target point.

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of points.
  • point (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The target point.
  • index (bool) – Whether to return the point or its index in the list.
Return type:

Union[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]], int]
Returns:

If index is False, returns point, otherwise returns index of point in list.
algoraphics.geom.horizontal_range(points)¶

Get the magnitude of the horizontal range of a list of points.

Parameters:points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of points.
Return type:Union[int, float]
algoraphics.geom.interpolate(points, spacing)¶

Insert interpolated points.

Insert equally-spaced, linearly interpolated points into list such that consecutive points are no more than ‘spacing’ distance apart.

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of points.
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – Maximum distance between adjacent points.
algoraphics.geom.is_clockwise(points)¶

Determine the derection of a sequence of points around a polygon.

Finds whether a set of polygon points goes in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction. If edges cross, it gives the more prominent direction.

Parameters:points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of polygon vertices.
Return type:bool
algoraphics.geom.jitter_points(points, r)¶

Add noise to the locations of points.

Distance and direction of movement are both uniformly random, so the 2D probability density is circular with higher concentration toward the center.

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of points.
  • r (Union[int, float]) – The maximum distance points will move.
algoraphics.geom.jittered_points(points, r)¶

Get noisy copy of points.

Like jitter_points but returns jittered points, not affecting the original list.

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of points.
  • r (Union[int, float]) – The maximum distance points will move.
Return type:

Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]
Returns:

A list of points.
algoraphics.geom.line_to_polygon(points, width)¶

Convert a sequence of points to a thin outline.

Imagining the points were connected with a stroke with positive width, the outline of the stroke is returned.

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of line points.
  • width (Union[int, float]) – Width of the stroke to be outlined.
Return type:

Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]
Returns:

A list of points.
algoraphics.geom.midpoint(p1, p2)¶

Get the midpoint between two points.

Parameters:
  • p1 (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – A point.
  • p2 (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – Another point.
Return type:

Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]
algoraphics.geom.move_toward(start, target, distance)¶
Parameters:
  • start (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – Starting point.
  • target (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – Point to indicate direction from starting point to move.
  • distance (Union[int, float]) – Distance from starting point to returned point.
Return type:

Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]
Returns:

A point distance from start in the direction of target.
algoraphics.geom.points_on_arc(center, radius, theta_start, theta_end, spacing)¶

Generate points along an arc.

Parameters:
  • center (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The center of the arc.
  • radius (Union[int, float]) – The radius of the arc.
  • theta_start (Union[int, float]) – The starting position in degrees.
  • theta_end (Union[int, float]) – The ending position in degrees.
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – The approximate distance between adjacent points.
Return type:

Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]
Returns:

A list of points.
algoraphics.geom.points_on_line(start, end, spacing)¶

Generate points along a line.

  • end (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The last point.
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – The approximate (max) distance between adjacent points.
Return type:

algoraphics.geom.rotate_and_move(start, ref, angle, distance)¶

Combine rotated_point and move_toward for convenience.

Parameters:
  • start (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – Starting point.
  • ref (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – A reference point.
  • angle (float) – The angle in radians to rotate ref around start.
  • distance (Union[int, float]) – The distance to move from start.
Returns:

A point distance from start in the angle direction relative to ref.
algoraphics.geom.rotate_points(points, pivot, angle)¶

Rotate points around a reference point.

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Union[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]], Sequence[+T_co]]]) – A list of points, which can be nested.
  • pivot (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The center of rotation.
  • angle (Union[int, float]) – The angle in radians by which to rotate.
algoraphics.geom.rotated_point(point, pivot, angle)¶

Get the new location of a point after rotating around a reference point.

Parameters:
  • point (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The starting location.
  • pivot (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The center of rotation.
  • angle (Union[int, float]) – The angle in radians by which to rotate.
Return type:

Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]
algoraphics.geom.scale_points(points, cx, cy=None)¶

Scale the coordinates of points.

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Union[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]], Sequence[+T_co]]]) – A list of points, which can be nested.
  • cx (Union[int, float]) – The horizontal scale factor.
  • cy (Union[int, float, None]) – The vertical scale factor. If omitted, y-coordinates will be scaled by cx.
algoraphics.geom.scaled_point(point, cx, cy=None)¶

Get the new location of point after scaling coordinates.

Provide either one scaling factor or cx and cy.

Parameters:
  • cx (Union[int, float]) – Either the scaling factor, or if cy is also provided, the horizontal scaling factor.
  • cy (Union[int, float, None]) – The vertical scaling factor.
Return type:

Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]
algoraphics.geom.spaced_points(n, bounds, n_cand=10)¶

Generate random but evenly-spaced points.

Uses Mitchell’s best-candidate algorithm.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – Number of points to generate.
  • bounds (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – A bounds tuple.
  • n_cand (int) – Number of candidate points to generate for each output point. Higher numbers result in higher regularity.
Return type:

List[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]
Returns:

The generated points.
algoraphics.geom.translate_points(points, dx, dy)¶

Shift the location of points.

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Union[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]], Sequence[+T_co]]]) – A list of points, which can be nested.
  • dx (Union[int, float]) – Horizontal change.
  • dy (Union[int, float]) – Vertical change.
algoraphics.geom.translated_point(point, dx, dy)¶

Get a translated point.

Parameters:
  • point (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The starting location.
  • dx (Union[int, float]) – The horizontal translation.
  • dy (Union[int, float]) – The vertical translation.
Return type:

Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]

grid.py¶

Functions for working with grids.

algoraphics.grid.grid_tree(rows, cols)¶

Generate random spanning tree for a grid.

Tree connects adjacent elements of a grid. Used for pixels and for other grids.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows in the grid.
  • cols (int) – Number of columns in the grid.
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

A 2D binary array in sparse format with dimensions (num. grid cells x num. grid cells) indicating which cells are connected.
algoraphics.grid.grid_tree_dists(rows, cols)¶

Generate an array of random spanning tree distances.

Each value is the distance to (0, 0) along a spanning tree. Map to a cyclical color gradient to create a billowing effect.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows in the grid.
  • cols (int) – Number of columns in the grid.
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

A 2D array of integers.
algoraphics.grid.grid_tree_edges(rows, cols)¶

Generate edges of a random spanning tree for a grid.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows in the grid.
  • cols (int) – Number of columns in the grid.
Return type:

Sequence[Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]]]
Returns:

A list of ((r1, c1), (r2, c2)) coordinate tuple pairs.
algoraphics.grid.grid_tree_neighbors(rows, cols)¶

Generate a random spanning tree for a grid and return neighbor array.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows in grid.
  • cols (int) – Number of cols in grid.
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

A 3D boolean array (rows x cols x [d?, r?, u?, l?]). The third dimension is length 4 and indicates whether that cell shares an edge with the cell below, right, above, and left of it.

images.py¶

Generate graphics based on images.

algoraphics.images.fill_shapes_from_image(shapes, image)¶

Fill shapes according to their corresponding image region.

Faster than region_color which samples points, but should only be used for regular shapes like tiles since it colors according to the centroid, which may not be inside the shape if it is irregular.

Parameters:
  • shapes – A list of shapes.
  • image – A PIL image.
algoraphics.images.image_regions(image, n_segments=100, compactness=10, smoothness=0, simplify=1, expand=2, smoothing=0.2)¶

Get spline shapes corresponding to image regions.

Parameters:
  • image – A PIL image.
  • n_segments – Approximate number of desired segments.
  • compactness – A higher value produces more compact, square-like segments. Try values along log-scale, e.g. 0.1, 1, 10, 100.
  • smoothness – The width of gaussian smoothing applied before segmentation.
  • simplify – Maximum distance from the edge of a simplified shape to its actual boundary when reducing the number of points, or None for no simplification.
  • expand – Number of pixels to expand each segment in every direction to avoid gaps between adjacent shapes.
  • smoothing – The degree of curvature in spline. Usually between zero and one.
Returns:

A list of spline shapes, generally in order from left to right and then bottom to top.
algoraphics.images.open_image(path)¶

Load a PIL image from file.

Parameters:path – Path to the image file.
Returns:A PIL Image.
algoraphics.images.pad_array(pixels, margin=1)¶

Create a new pixel array with added padding.

Adds additional rows and columns of zeros to four edges of matrix. Used to enable finding a contour around a segment at the edge of an image and to allow segments to be expanded to overlap each other.

Parameters:
  • pixels (ndarray) – A 2D array of pixels.
  • margin (int) – The width of padding on each side.
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

A 2D array with 2 * margin added to both dimensions.
algoraphics.images.region_color(outline, image, n_points=10)¶

Find representative color for an image region.

Parameters:
  • outline – A shape corresponding to an image region to sample.
  • image – A PIL image.
  • n_points – Number of points to sample.
Returns:

The average color of the sampled image points.
algoraphics.images.resize_image(image, width, height)¶

Downscale an image.

Scales according to whichever of width or height is not None. Only scales down.

Parameters:
  • image – A PIL image.
  • width – The new width. If None, scales according to height.
  • height – The new height. If None, scales according to width.
algoraphics.images.sample_colors(image, points)¶

Sample colors from an image.

Parameters:
  • image – A PIL image.
  • points – A list of image coordinates, or a single coordinate.
Returns:

A list of colors corresponding to points, or a single color if input is a single point.
algoraphics.images.segment_image(image, n_segments=100, compactness=10, smoothness=0)¶

Divide image into segments.

Used by image_regions().

Parameters:
  • image – A PIL image.
  • n_segments – Approximate number of desired segments.
  • compactness – A higher value produces more compact, square-like segments. Try values along log-scale, e.g. 0.1, 1, 10, 100.
  • smoothness – The width of gaussian smoothing applied before segmentation.
Returns:

A 2D array of integer segment labels.
algoraphics.images.segments_to_shapes(seg, simplify=None, expand=1, smoothing=0.2)¶

Convert an array of segment labels to spline shapes.

Used by image_regions().

Parameters:
  • seg (ndarray) – A 2D array of segment labels.
  • simplify (Union[int, float, None]) – Maximum distance from the edge of a simplified shape to the actual boundary when reducing number of points, or None for no simplification.
  • expand (int) – Number of pixels to expand each segment in every direction to avoid gaps between adjacent shapes.
  • smoothing (float) – The degree of curvature for the splines. Usually between zero and one.
Return type:

Sequence[dict]
Returns:

A list of spline shapes, generally in order from left to right and then bottom to top.

main.py¶

General functions for creating graphics.

algoraphics.main.add_margin(bounds, margin)¶

Add margin to bounds.

A convenience function used when generating objects to avoid issues at the edges of the region or canvas.

Parameters:
  • bounds (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – A tuple of min x, min y, max x, and max y.
  • margin (Union[int, float]) – The width of the margin.
Return type:

Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]
Returns:

Bounds that include the margin on all sides.
algoraphics.main.flatten(objects)¶

Create a flattened list from a nested list.

Parameters:objects (Any) – A nested list or a non-list.
Return type:list
Returns:The non-list elements within the input.
algoraphics.main.random_walk(min_val, max_val, max_step, n, start=None)¶

Generate a random walk sequence.

Steps are sampled from a uniform random distribution.

Parameters:
  • min_val (Union[int, float]) – Values will not fall below this value.
  • max_val (Union[int, float]) – Values will not fall above this value.
  • max_step (Union[int, float]) – Maximum magnitude of each step.
  • n (int) – Length of the sequence.
  • start (Union[int, float, None]) – The starting value.
Return type:

list
Returns:

The generated sequence.
algoraphics.main.region_background(region, color)¶

Add background color to a clipped region.

Adds a filled rectangle to the beginning of the region’s members.

Parameters:
  • region (dict) – A clipped group shape.
  • color (Color) – A color to apply to the region.
algoraphics.main.reorder_objects(objects, by='random', w=None, h=None)¶

Reorder objects in list.

Used to change order in which objects are drawn.

Parameters:
  • objects (Sequence[Union[list, dict]]) – A list whose items are shapes or lists.
  • by (str) – ‘random’ to shuffle objects. ‘out to in’ to arrange objects closer to the center on top of (later in list) those further from the center. Distance is determined by furthest corner of bounding box so that smaller objects tend to be arranged on top of larger ones that surround them.
  • w (Union[int, float, None]) – Canvas width, used to get center when by=’out to in’.
  • h (Union[int, float, None]) – Canvas height, used to get center when by=’out to in’.
algoraphics.main.shuffled(items)¶

Create shuffled version of a list.

Parameters:items (Sequence[+T_co]) – A list of items.
Return type:list
Returns:A new list with same objects as input but reordered.
algoraphics.main.tint_region(region, color, opacity)¶

Add color tint to a clipped region.

Parameters:
  • region (dict) – A clipped group shape.
  • color (Color) – The tint color.
  • opacity (float) – The degree of tinting from 0 to 1.

param.py¶

Define parameter objects that incorporate randomness.

class algoraphics.param.Cyclical(low=-1, high=1, period=8, phase=0)¶

Parameters that oscillate between values.

Its low value, high value, and period can be Params to add randomness to the cycle.

Parameters:
  • low (Union[int, float]) – The minimum value (wave trough).
  • high (Union[int, float]) – The maximum value (wave peak).
  • period (Union[int, float]) – The number of values returned per oscillation. It need not be an integer.
  • phase (Union[int, float]) – The starting offset of sine oscillation in degrees. The default of zero starts halfway between low and high and increases.
value()¶

Generate a value.

class algoraphics.param.Delta(start=None, delta=None, ratio=None, min=None, max=None)¶

Parameters whose values depend on the previous value.

Provide a Param or number for delta which will be added to the previously generated value to get the next one. Or, provide a ratio Param or number to multiply to each previous value.

Passing a randomized Param object to delta or ratio will result in a random walk. These Param objects can themselves have a delta/ratio argument, resulting in higher-order random walks.

Parameters:
  • start – The starting value, which can be obtained from a Param.
  • delta – A value to add to the previous value to get the next.
  • ratio – Similar to delta, but is multiplied by, rather than added to, the previous value to get the next.
  • min – The smallest allowable value.
  • max – The largest allowable value.
class algoraphics.param.Exponential(mean=1, stdev=1, sigma=2)¶

Parameters with Exponential distributions.

Parameters:
  • mean (Union[int, float]) – The distribution’s mean.
  • stdev (Union[int, float]) – The distribution’s standard deviation.
  • sigma (Union[int, float]) – How many standard deviations from the mean to clip values.
value()¶

Generate a value.

class algoraphics.param.Normal(mean=0, stdev=1)¶

Parameters with Gaussian (normal) distributions.

Parameters:
  • mean (Union[int, float]) – The distribution’s mean.
  • stdev (Union[int, float]) – The distribution’s standard deviation.
value()¶

Generate a value.

class algoraphics.param.Param(x)¶

Objects to represent fixed or random parameters for shapes.

Create Param objects for fixed values, value lists, or arbitrary functions. For random distributions, use a specific class that inherits from Param.

Parameters:x (Union[str, float, int, list, Callable]) – A value, list, or a function that takes no arguments and returns a value.
class algoraphics.param.Place(ref, direction=None, distance=0)¶

An object that generates points with respect to a reference point.

It is the 2D version of Param, and uses polar coordinates.

Parameters:
  • ref (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The reference or starting point.
  • direction (Optional[Param]) – A param giving directions (in degrees) of generated points relative to ref. By default the direction is uniformly random.
  • distance (Param) – A param giving distances of generated points relative to ref.
value()¶

Generate points relative to reference.

class algoraphics.param.Uniform(min=0, max=1)¶

Parameters with uniformly random distributions.

Parameters:
  • min (Union[int, float]) – The lower bound.
  • max (Union[int, float]) – The upper bound.
value()¶

Generate a value.

class algoraphics.param.Wander(start, direction=0, distance=0)¶

An object that generates points relative to the previous point.

Just as Place is the 2D version of Param, Wander is the 2D version of Delta.

Parameters:delta_direc – A param giving the direction to move in e

Return type:Union[int, float, str]
algoraphics.param.make_param(x)¶

Get a Param object even if something else is supplied.

If a Param object is supplied, a deep copy is generated in case it has a delta or ratio and is being reused.

Return type:Param
algoraphics.param.make_place(x)¶

Get a Place object even if a fixed point is supplied.

Return type:Param

ripples.py¶

Create space-filling ripple effects.

algoraphics.ripples.ripple_canvas(w, h, spacing, trans_probs=None, existing_pts=None)¶

Fill the canvas with ripples.

The behavior of the ripples is determined by a first-order Markov chain in which events correspond to points along splines. The states are ‘S’, ‘R’, ‘L’, and ‘X’. At ‘S’, the ripple begins in a random direction. At ‘R’, the ripple turns right sharply until encountering a ripple or other barrier, and then follows along it. Likewise with ‘L’ turning left. At ‘X’, the ripple moves straight forward +/- up to 60 degrees. Higher state-changing transition probabilities result in more erratic ripples.

Parameters:
  • w (Union[int, float]) – Width of the canvas.
  • h (Union[int, float]) – Height of the canvas.
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – Distance between ripples.
  • trans_probs (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, float]]]) – A dictionary of dictionaries containing Markov chain transition probabilities from one state (first key) to another (second key).
  • existing_pts (Optional[Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]]) – An optional list of points that ripples will avoid.
Return type:

List[dict]
Returns:

The ripple splines.

algoraphics.shapes.remove_hidden(shapes)¶

Remove shapes from (nested) list if they are entirely covered.

Used to optimize SVG file without altering appearance, e.g. when randomly placing objects to fill a region. Ignores opacity when determining overlap.

Parameters:shapes (Sequence[Union[list, dict]]) – A list of shapes.
algoraphics.shapes.reposition(shapes, position, h_align='left', v_align='bottom')¶

Align one or more shapes to a reference point.

Parameters:
  • shapes (Union[list, dict]) – One or more shapes.
  • poisition – The reference point.
  • h_align (str) – ‘left’ to move left bound to reference point. ‘center’ to horizontally center object around reference point. ‘right’ to move right bound to reference point.
  • v_align (str) – ‘bottom’ to move lower bound to reference point. ‘middle’ to vertically center object around reference point. ‘top’ to move upper bound to reference point.

Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]
Returns:

The min x, max x, min y, and max y coordinates in rotated space. Anything created using these coordinates must then be rotated by the same angle around the origin to be in the right place.

Create a spline shape.

  • smoothing (Union[int, float]) – The distance to the control point relative to the distance to the adjacent point. Usually between zero and one.
  • circular (bool) – If False, spline ends reasonably at the first and last points. If True, the ends of the spline will connect smoothly.

forms.py¶

Create forms such as filaments and trees.

algoraphics.structures.blow_paint_area(points, spacing=20, length=40, len_dev=0.25, width=5)¶

Draw a blow-paint effect around an area.

Creates ‘fingers’ of paint projecting from each edge, as if being blown along the page perpindicular to the edge.

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – The vertices of the polygonal area.
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – Average distance between paint fingers.
  • length (Union[int, float]) – Average length of the paint fingers.
  • len_dev (float) – The standard deviation of finger lengths relative to length (so it should be less than 1).
  • width (Union[int, float]) – Average thickness of each finger.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.structures.blow_paint_line(points, line_width=10, spacing=20, length=20, len_dev=0.33, width=5)¶

Draw a blow-paint effect connecting a sequence of points.

Creates ‘fingers’ of paint projecting from each edge, as if being blown along the page perpindicular to the edge (in both directions).

Parameters:
  • points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – The points to connect.
  • line_width (Union[int, float]) – The thickness of the line (excluding the fingers).
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – Average distance between paint fingers.
  • length (Union[int, float]) – Average length of the paint fingers.
  • len_dev (float) – The standard deviation of finger lengths relative to length (so it should be less than 1).
  • width (Union[int, float]) – Average thickness of each finger.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.structures.blow_paint_spot(point, length=10, len_dev=0.7, width=3)¶

Draw a paint splatter.

Creates ‘fingers’ of paint projecting from a point.

Parameters:
  • point (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The center of the splatter.
  • length (Union[int, float]) – Average length of the paint fingers.
  • len_dev (float) – The standard deviation of finger lengths relative to length (so it should be less than 1).
  • width (Union[int, float]) – Average thickness of each finger.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.structures.filament(start, direction, width, seg_length, n_segments)¶

Generate a meandering segmented filament.

Parameters:
  • start (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The midpoint of first edge of the filament.
  • direction (Param) – The direction (in degrees) of each segment. Recommended to be a Delta for a meandering filament. Nested Deltas will produce meandering from higher-order random walks.
  • width (Param) – The width of the filament (at segment joining edges).
  • seg_length (Param) – Average side length of each segment.
  • n_segments (int) – Number of segments in the filament.
Return type:

List[dict]
Returns:

A list of polygons (the segments from start to end).
algoraphics.structures.tentacle(start, direction, length, width, seg_length)¶

Generate a filament that tapers to a point.

Parameters:
  • start (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The midpoint of first edge of the tentacle.
  • direction (Param) – The direction (in degrees) of each segment. Recommended to be a Delta for a meandering filament. Nested Deltas will produce meandering from higher-order random walks.
  • length (Union[int, float]) – Approximate length of the tentacle.
  • width (Param) – The starting width of the tentacle.
  • seg_length (Union[int, float]) – Average starting length of each segment. They will shrink toward to the tip.
Return type:

List[dict]
Returns:

A list of polygons (the segments from base to tip).
algoraphics.structures.tree(start, direction, branch_length, theta, p)¶

Generate a tree with randomly terminating branches.

Parameters:
  • start (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The starting point.
  • direction (Union[int, float]) – The starting direction (in degrees).
  • branch_length (Param) – Branch length.
  • theta (Param) – The angle (in degrees) between sibling branches.
  • p (Param) – The probability that a given branch will split instead of terminating. Recommended to have a delta < 0 or ratio < 1 so that the tree is guaranteed to terminate.
Return type:

List[dict]
Returns:

A list of line shapes.
algoraphics.structures.wave(start, direction, period, length)¶

Generate a wave spline.

The wave is generated as a series of points generated with oscillating direction from the previous. This allows for different forms of randomness and dynamics to be used, but amplitude is not independent of period. All wave specifications are approximate.

Parameters:
  • start (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – Starting point of the wave.
  • direction (Union[int, float]) – Starting direction (in degrees) of the wave.
  • period (Union[int, float]) – Peak-to-peak distance.
  • length (Union[int, float]) – End-to-end length of the wave.
Return type:

dict
Returns:

A spline shape.

svg.py¶

write SVG files.

algoraphics.svg.svg_string(objects, w, h)¶

Create an SVG string for a collection of objects.

Parameters:
  • objects (Union[list, dict]) – A (nested) collection of objects. They are placed onto the canvas in order after flattening.
  • w (Union[int, float]) – Width of the canvas.
  • h (Union[int, float]) – Height of the canvas.
algoraphics.svg.to_PNG(infile, outfile=None)¶

Convert and SVG file to a PNG image.

Parameters:
  • infile (str) – The SVG file name.
  • outfile (Optional[str]) – The PNG file name to write to. If omitted, it will be set to the SVG file name with the extension replaced with ‘.png’.
algoraphics.svg.write_SVG(objects, w, h, file_name, optimize=True)¶

Write an SVG file for a collection of objects.

Parameters:
  • objects (Union[list, dict]) – A (nested) collection of objects. They are placed onto the canvas in order after flattening.
  • w (Union[int, float]) – Width of canvas.
  • h (Union[int, float]) – Height of canvas.
  • file_name (str) – The file name to write to.
  • optimize (bool) – Whether to optimize the SVG file using svgo.
algoraphics.svg.write_frames(fun, n, w, h, file_name)¶

Write multiple frames of randomized objects.

Frames can then be combined into an animated GIF.

Parameters:
  • fun (Callable) – A function called with no arguments that returns an SVG object collection.
  • n (int) – Number of frames to generate.
  • w (Union[int, float]) – Width of the canvas.
  • h (Union[int, float]) – Height of the canvas.
  • file_name (str) – A file name (without extension) to write to. File names will be [file_name]_0.svg, etc.

text.py¶

Generate text in the form of shapes or SVG text.

algoraphics.text.char_points(char, start, h, spacing)¶

Generate points along a character shape.

Parameters:
  • char (str) – A character.
  • start (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The lower-left point of the character bounds.
  • h (Union[int, float]) – The line height.
  • spacing (Union[int, float]) – Distance between adjacent points.
Return type:

List[List[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]]
Returns:

A list of lists of points. Each list of points corresponds to a pen stroke (i.e. what can be drawn without lifting the pen).
algoraphics.text.text_points(text, height, pt_spacing, char_spacing=0.1, grouping='points')¶

Generate points that spell out text.

Text starts at (0, 0) and should be repositioned.

Parameters:
  • text (str) – The text.
  • height (Union[int, float]) – Line height.
  • pt_spacing (Union[int, float]) – Approximate distance between adjacent points.
  • char_spacing (Union[int, float]) – Size of the largest space on either side of each character relative to line height. This space is shrunk for certain characters depending on shape.
  • grouping (str) – ‘points’ to return list of points, ‘strokes’ to group by stroke.
Return type:

Union[List[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]], List[List[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]]]
Returns:

Either a list of points or a list of lists of points in which each list of points corresponds to a pen stroke (i.e. what can be drawn without lifting the pin).

textures.py¶

Add textures and shadows to shapes.

algoraphics.textures.add_paper_texture(obj)¶

Recursively apply paper texture to shapes.

Parameters:obj (Union[list, dict]) – A shape or (nested) list of shapes.
algoraphics.textures.add_shadows(objects, stdev=10, darkness=0.5)¶

Add shadows to objects.

Each element (nested or not) of the list is replaced with a group with shadow filter. So items that are shapes will have their own shadow, while an item that is a (nested) list of shapes will have one shadow for the composite object.

Parameters:
  • objects (Sequence[Union[list, dict]]) – A list of shapes (can be nested).
  • stdev (Union[int, float]) – Standard deviation of the shadow gradient.
  • darkness (Union[int, float]) – A number below one for lighter shadow, above one for darker.
algoraphics.textures.array_to_image(array, scale=True)¶

Create an image from a 2D or 3D array.

Parameters:
  • array – A numpy array: 2D for grayscale or 3D for RGB.
  • scale – If True, values in 2D array will be scaled so that the highest values are 255 (white).
Returns:

A PIL Image in RGB mode.
algoraphics.textures.billow_region(outline, colors, scale=200, gradient_mode='rgb')¶

Fill region with billowing texture.

Parameters:
  • outline (Union[list, dict]) – The object that will become the clip.
  • colors (Sequence[Color]) – A list of Colors to cycle through.
  • scale (int) – The distance in pixels for each color cycle.
  • gradient_mode (str) – ‘rgb’ or ‘hsl’ to indicate how the gradient is interpolated.
Return type:

dict
Returns:

A group with clip.
algoraphics.textures.billowing(w, h, colors, scale, gradient_mode='rgb')¶

Generate a billowing texture.

Parameters:
  • w – Width of the texture.
  • h – Height of the texture.
  • colors – A list of Color objects to cycle through.
  • scale – Distance in pixels for each color cycle.
  • gradient_mode – ‘rgb’ or ‘hsl’ to choose the appearance of the gradient.
Returns:

A PIL image object.
algoraphics.textures.filtered(obj, fltr)¶

Apply a filter to one or more shapes.

Parameters:
  • obj (Union[list, dict]) – A shape or (nested) list.
  • fltr (dict) – A filter.
Return type:

dict
Returns:

A group with obj as members and filter applied to group.
algoraphics.textures.tear_paper_rect(objects, bounds)¶

Add effect of tearing a rectangle around a shape or collection.

Parameters:
  • objects (Union[list, dict]) – A shape or (nested) list of shapes.
  • bounds (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – A rectangle will be torn just inside these bounds.
Return type:

dict
Returns:

A shadow-filtered group containing a clipped group containing original shapes.
algoraphics.textures.with_shadow(obj, stdev, darkness)¶

Add shadow to an object.

Like add_shadows() but returns a group with a single shadow filter.

Parameters:
  • obj (Union[list, dict]) – A shape or list of objects (can be nested).
  • stdev (Union[int, float]) – Standard deviation of shadow gradient.
  • darkness (Union[int, float]) – A number below one for lighter shadow, above one for darker.
Return type:

dict
Returns:

A group with obj as members and a filter applied to the group.

tiling.py¶

Fill a region or the canvas with tiles or webs.

algoraphics.tiling.delaunay_edges(points)¶

Parameters:points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of points.
Return type:List[dict]
Returns:A list of line shapes.
algoraphics.tiling.delaunay_regions(points)¶

Find the Delaunay regions for a set of points.

Parameters:points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of points.
Return type:List[dict]
Returns:A list of triangular polygon shapes. Items do not correspond to input points because points on the periphery do not have finite regions.
algoraphics.tiling.fill_nested_triangles(outline, min_level, max_level, color=None, color2=None)¶

Fill region with nested triangle pattern.

Parameters:
  • outline (Union[list, dict]) – A region outline shape or collection.
  • min_level (int) – The level of the largest triangles (0 is bounding triangle).
  • max_level (int) – The level of the smallest triangles.
  • color1 – The color/s for half of the triangles.
  • color2 (Optional[Color]) – The color for the opposing half of the triangles. This half of triangles will all be one color because it is the background.
Return type:

dict
Returns:

A group with the outline as clip.
algoraphics.tiling.nested_triangles(tip, height, min_level, max_level)¶

Generate nested equilateral triangles.

Parameters:
  • tip (Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]) – The tip of the bounding triangle.
  • height (Union[int, float]) – The height of the bounding triangle (negative for upside-down triangle).
  • min_level (int) – The level of the largest triangles (0 is the bounding triangle).
  • max_level (int) – The level of the smallest triangles.
Return type:

List[dict]
Returns:

A list of triangle polygon shapes.
algoraphics.tiling.tile_canvas(w, h, shape='polygon', edges=False, tile_size=500, regularity=10)¶

Fill canvas with (uncolored) tiles.

Parameters:
  • w (Union[int, float]) – Width of the canvas.
  • h (Union[int, float]) – Height of the canvas.
  • tile_shape – Either ‘polygon’ for Voronoi tiling or ‘triangle’ for Delaunay tiling.
  • edges (bool) – Whether to return the edges around tiles as lines instead of the tiles themselves.
  • tile_size (Union[int, float]) – The approximate area of each tile.
  • regularity (int) – A value of one or higher, passed to spaced_points.
Return type:

List[dict]
Returns:

A list of polygon or line shapes.
algoraphics.tiling.tile_region(outline, shape='polygon', edges=False, tile_size=500, regularity=10)¶

Fill region with (uncolored) tiles or tile edges.

Parameters:
  • outline (Union[list, dict]) – The shape/s that will become the clip.
  • shape (str) – Either ‘polygon’ for Voronoi tiling or ‘triangle’ for Delaunay tiling.
  • edges (bool) – Whether to return the edges around tiles as lines instead of the tiles themselves.
  • tile_size (Union[int, float]) – The approximate area of each tile.
  • regularity (int) – A value of one or higher, passed to spaced_points().
Return type:

dict
Returns:

A group with clip.
algoraphics.tiling.voronoi_edges(points)¶

Find the edges of Voronoi regions for a set of points.

Parameters:points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of points.
Return type:List[dict]
Returns:A list of line shapes.
algoraphics.tiling.voronoi_regions(points)¶

Find Voronoi regions for a set of points.

Parameters:points (Sequence[Tuple[Union[int, float], Union[int, float]]]) – A list of points.
Return type:List[dict]
Returns:A list of polygon shapes. Items do not correspond to input points because points on the periphery do not have finite regions.
